   Mg++:1.5 mg/dL, PO4:2.2 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
 SEPSIS, SEVERE (WITH ORGAN DYSFUNCTION)
 .H/O PULMONARY HYPERTENSION (PULM HTN, PHTN)
 .H/O CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD, BRONCHITIS,
   EMPHYSEMA) WITH ACUTE EXACERBATION
   This is a 55 year-old female with a history of COPD and respiratory
   failure, MAT/a-flutter, who was intially admitted to [**Hospital3 **]
   with MAT/a-fib, respiratory distress, intubated and treated for UTI and
   transferred per family request.
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever
   (101-103), and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate 3.7.  Likely source is
   urinary vs respiratory vs line infection. The patient has been at [**Hospital **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial infections are high on the
   differential. The patient's hypotension is likely multifactorial.
   Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter with rapid rate, likely
   infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line infection.  She was placed
   on levophed gtt and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna vs effusion vs pulm edema
   vs ARDS.
   - likely secondary to infx per above: continue vanc/[**Last Name (un) 430**]/amikacin.
   - ID c/s today
   - call OSH for sensitivities
   - TTE today to assess for cardiac fxn
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12, trend lactate, trend WBC/diff
   - IV fluid boluses
   - Levophed and Neo to maintain MAP > 65 and UOP > 30cc/hr, but may use
   dopa depending on Echo
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30 if remains in spetic shock
   - cont treatment with Amikacin given Proteus in urine and pseudomonas
   in sputum
   - check amikacin peak and trough
   - repeat CXR in AM
   - f/u BCx, Ucx, sputum, pull line and culture tip
   - stress dose steriods, increase to solumedrol 60 [**Hospital1 **] (pt was on 2d ago
   at OSH)
   - cooling blankets prn
   .
   #. Tachycardia: Pt with MAT/a-flutter Her rates on admission were as
   high as 150-180's.  She was started on amio (bolus 150mg, then 1mg/hr)
   due to hypotension nodal agents were deferred.  Her fast rate is likely
   contributing to her hypotension.  She was previously controlled on po
   lopressor, dilt and dig. Also on the differential is possible
   underlying PE driving her tachycardia, although given Hct drop would
   not start anti-coagulation.  Additionally, sepsis and pain also likely
   driving her tachycardia. Cardioverted yesterday night into sinus tach
   (130-140s)
   - cont Amio gtt for now, hold nodal agents given hemodynamic instab [**2-25**]
   septic shock per above, wait for TTE
   - repeat ECG in AM
   - hold on anti-coagulation given bleeding and Hct drop
   - LENI to r/o DVT
   - first set CE neg, will ROMI
   - check dig level
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt with COPD and frequent admissions for
   respiratory failure.  She was initially admitted to and placed on
   BiPAP, but required intubtion after desat. ABG here showed
   7.35/74/162/43. AC 540/15/5/100%. Possible PNA given pseudomonas in
   sputum and as well as chronic aspirations. CXR showed b/l diffuse
   infiltrates/effusions R>L. DDx: Multi-focal Pneumonia, pulmonart edema
   Aspiration pneumonitis, effusision, ARDS
   - CXR in AM
   - cont methylpred
   - albuterol/ ipratropium nebs
   - Pt likely lives at an elevated PCO2 given elevated Bicarb. Pt also
   autopeeping and thus will increase PEEP to 10 and attempt to decrease
   RR.  Will follow closely with ABG.
   .
   #. Anemia: Pt Hct on admission was 21.9. This is down from 25 at the
   OSH. Pt with multiple ecchymosis on exam.  No evidence of active
   bleeding. Other possiblities could be RP or intraperitonea bleed.
   - active T&C 4U
   - Transfuse 2U pRBC and repeat Hct
   - hemolysis labs
   - guaiac stools
   - if continues to drop Hct plan for CT-torso
   .
   #. Thrombocytopenia: Pt plts 125. HIT negative at OSH. Stable, will
   cont to monitor and trend.
   #. UTI: See above. Growing proteus in urine.
   - cont amikacin for now
   - repeat UA/UCx
   .
   #. Pseudomonas Sputum: growing from sputum. Question as to whether
   colonization vs active infection. CXR was reportly normal at OSH. Is
   being covered with amikacin.
   - CXR
   - repeat sputum cx
   - cont amikacin
   - started meropenem
   .
   #. IDDM: Pt on steriods. Will initiated ISS and lantus 24U q12.
   Monitor QACHS FS and cover with ISS.
   .
   # FEN: NPO, will plan to initiate TF tomorrow. Nutrition consult
   .
   # Access: PICC line (placed at OSH)
   Left fem CVL, left radial a-line
   .
   # PPx: pneumoboots, PPI,
   .
   # Code: FULL CODE
   .
   # Dispo: ICU for now
   .
   # Comm: Family attempted to be contact[**Name (NI) **] at time of admission. Spoke
   with husband at length to update him overnight.
   Husband [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Name (NI) 9775**]) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9776**]
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   PICC Line - [**2165-8-16**] 06:50 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2165-8-16**] 09:00 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2165-8-16**] 10:30 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:
   Disposition:

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), respiratory failure, and atrial fibrillation (MAT/a-flutter). She was admitted to the ICU with severe sepsis, respiratory failure, and tachycardia. She has been treated with antibiotics, vasopressors, and mechanical ventilation. Her condition is complicated by multiple factors, including septic shock, respiratory failure, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and possible underlying pulmonary hypertension.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Septic Shock: The patient's septic shock is likely to worsen if not properly managed, leading to organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may progress to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) if not adequately managed, leading to further respiratory compromise and potential mortality.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not properly treated, leading to further compromise of her cardiovascular and respiratory systems.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may increase the risk of bleeding complications if not properly managed, potentially leading to further morbidity and mortality.
5. UTI: The patient's urinary tract infection (UTI) may progress to a more severe infection if not properly treated, leading to further septic shock and potential mortality.
6. Pseudomonas Sputum: The patient's pseudomonas sputum may indicate a more severe infection if not properly treated, leading to further respiratory compromise and potential mortality.
7. IDDM: The patient's insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM) may require adjustments in her treatment regimen to prevent hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia.
8. FEN: The patient's fasting status may require adjustments in her treatment regimen to prevent malnutrition and electrolyte imbalances.
9. Access: The patient's access lines may require adjustments to prevent complications such as line infections and bleeding.
10. PPx: The patient's pneumoboots and PPI may require adjustments to prevent further respiratory compromise and potential mortality.

Based on this information, it is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies to identify potential complications and adjust her treatment regimen accordingly.

 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
 SEPSIS, SEVERE (WITH ORGAN DYSFUNCTION)
 .H/O PULMONARY HYPERTENSION (PULM HTN, PHTN)
 .H/O CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD, BRONCHITIS,
   EMPHYSEMA) WITH ACUTE EXACERBATION
   This is a 55 year-old female with a history of COPD and respiratory
   failure, MAT/a-flutter, who was intially admitted to [**Hospital3 **]
   with MAT/a-fib, respiratory distress, intubated and treated for UTI and
   transferred per family request.
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever
   (101-103), and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate 3.7.  Likely source is
   urinary vs respiratory vs line infection. The patient has been at [**Hospital **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial infections are high on the
   differential. The patient's hypotension is likely multifactorial.
   Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter with rapid rate, likely
   infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line infection. She has h/o
   proteus UTI and pseudomonas in sputum. She was placed on levophed gtt
   and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna vs effusion vs pulm edema vs ARDS.
   - likely secondary to infx per above: continue vanc/[**Last Name (un) 430**]/amikacin
   - check amikacin trough
   - ID c/s today
   - call OSH for sensitivities
   - TTE today to assess for cardiac fxn
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12, trend lactate, trend WBC/diff
   - IV fluid boluses
   - Levophed and Neo to maintain MAP > 65 and UOP > 30cc/hr, but may use
   dopa depending on Echo
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30 if remains in spetic shock
   - repeat CXR in AM
   - f/u BCx, Ucx, sputum, pull line and culture tip
   - stress dose steriods, increase to solumedrol 60 [**Hospital1 **] (pt was on 2d ago
   at OSH)
   - cooling blankets prn
   .
   #. Tachycardia: Pt with MAT/a-flutter Her rates on admission were as
   high as 150-180's.  She was started on amio (bolus 150mg, then 1mg/hr)
   due to hypotension nodal agents were deferred.  Her fast rate is likely
   contributing to her hypotension.  She was previously controlled on po
   lopressor, dilt and dig. Also on the differential is possible
   underlying PE driving her tachycardia, although given Hct drop would
   not start anti-coagulation, and d-dimer low so PE unlikely.
   Additionally, sepsis and pain also likely driving her tachycardia.
   Cardioverted yesterday night into sinus tach (130-140s)
   - cont Amio gtt for now, hold nodal agents given hemodynamic instab [**2-25**]
   septic shock per above, wait for TTE
   - repeat ECG in AM
   - hold on anti-coagulation given bleeding and Hct drop
   - first set CE neg, will ROMI
   - check dig level
   .
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt with COPD and frequent admissions for
   respiratory failure.  She was initially admitted to and placed on
   BiPAP, but required intubtion after desat. ABG here showed
   7.35/74/162/43. AC 540/15/5/100%. Possible PNA given pseudomonas in
   sputum and as well as chronic aspirations. CXR showed b/l diffuse
   infiltrates/effusions R>L. DDx: Multi-focal Pneumonia, pulmonart edema
   Aspiration pneumonitis, effusision, ARDS
   - CXR in AM
   - cont methylpred
   - albuterol/ ipratropium nebs
   - Pt likely lives at an elevated PCO2 given elevated Bicarb. Pt also
   autopeeping and thus will increase PEEP and attempt to decrease RR.
   Will follow closely with ABG.
   .
   # Oliguria: BUN and Cr are normal right now. However given septic shock
   there is concern for poor renal blood flow, and the possibility for
   development of ATN and future need for CVVH given IVF need.
   - check [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   - monitor UOP closely, gentle IVF
   .
   #. Anemia: Pt Hct on admission was 21.9. This is down from 25 at the
   OSH. Pt with multiple ecchymosis on exam.  No evidence of active
   bleeding. Other possiblities could be RP or intraperitoneal bleed.  HCT
   stable now at 31.
   - active T&C 4U
   - follow CBCs
   - hemolysis labs
   - guaiac stools
   - if continues to drop Hct plan for CT-torso
   .
   #. Thrombocytopenia: Pt plts low 100s. HIT negative at OSH. Stable,
   will cont to monitor and trend.
   .
   #. IDDM: Pt on steriods. Will initiated ISS and lantus 24U q12.
   Monitor QACHS FS and cover with ISS.
   .
   # FEN: NPO, will plan to initiate TF tomorrow. Nutrition consult
   .
   # Access: PICC line (placed at OSH)
   Left fem CVL, left radial a-line
   .
   # PPx: pneumoboots, PPI,
   .
   # Code: FULL CODE
   .
   # Dispo: ICU for now
   .
   # Comm: Family attempted to be contact[**Name (NI) **] at time of admission. Spoke
   with husband at length to update him overnight.
   Husband [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Name (NI) 9775**]) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9776**]
   ICU Care

   Arterial Line - [**2165-8-16**] 10:30 PM

   DVT: subcu heparin, pneumoboots
   Stress ulcer: PPI

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), pulmonary hypertension, and respiratory failure. She was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with septic shock, acute respiratory failure, and tachycardia.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101.4°F (38.6°C)
* Blood pressure: 120/69 mmHg
* Heart rate: 153 bpm
* Respiratory rate: 20 inspirations per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 93%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 4.0 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 10.8 g/dL
* Platelet count: 125 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.13 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 3.6 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.9 g/dL
* LDH: 641 IU/L
* Calcium: 6.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.5 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.2 mg/dL

The patient's respiratory support includes:

* Invasive ventilation with a tidal volume of 400 mL
* Positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 12 cmH2O
* Fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 100%

The patient's medical plan includes:

* Continuous infusion of norepinephrine and amiodarone
* Antibiotics for septic shock
* Stress dose steroids
* Cooling blankets as needed
* Repeat CXR in the morning
* Follow-up blood cultures, urine cultures, and sputum cultures

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis-induced organ dysfunction
* Respiratory failure
* Tachycardia
* Oliguria
* Anemia
* Thrombocytopenia
* IDDM
* FEN
* Access-related complications

The patient's code status is full code, and her disposition is ICU level of care.

   Assesment: This is a 55 year-old female with a history of COPD and
   respiratory failure, MAT/a-flutter, chronic steroid use, who was
   intially admitted to [**Hospital3 **] with MAT/a-fib, respiratory
   distress, intubated and treated for UTI and transferred per family
   request.
   .
   Plan:
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever,
   and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate elevated.  Likely source is
   respiratory, although urinary and line infection are possible. The
   patient has been at [**Hospital3 **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial
   infections are high on the differential. The patient's hypotension is
   likely multifactorial.  Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter
   with rapid rate, likely infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line
   infection.  She was placed on levophed gtt and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna
   vs effusion vs pulm edema vs ARDS.
   Hemodynamics
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12
   - IV fluid boluses and Levophed and Dopamine to maintain MAP > 65 and
   UOP > 30cc/hr. Avoid Neo due to vasoconstrictive effects on
   limbs/organs.
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30
   - consulted renal for possible CVVH to remove fluid. +~11 liters over
   24 hours
   Infection: broad coverage for C.diff, gram +/- including VRE. Bactrim
   because long term steroid use.
   - Sputum (4+ GNR, 4+GPC in [**Hospital1 54**] culture, OSH culture showing
   pseudomonas) and blood (GPC, GNR in [**Hospital1 54**] culture). Reported VRE
   surveillance positive in OSH culture.
   - Started linezolid ([**8-16**]), amikacin (started at OSH), flagyl.
   - cont treatment with Amikacin given Proteus in urine and pseudomonas
   in sputum, treat with linezolid for VRE coverage (positive screen at
   OSH), meropenem for pseudomonas double coverage, voriconazole (at risk
   of fungal infection given chronic steroid use)
   - Need to renally dose medications
   - f/u urine, sputum, blood cxs.
   - consider activated protein C in patient, however, bleeding risks
   outweigh benefit.
   - trend WBC, fever curve
   - ID approval of abx.
   Metabolic: Has AG metabolic acidosis, likely due to lactate. With low
   pH on ABG, worry about cardiac asystole.
   - Continue to trend lactate
   - dialysis will help with lactate clearance
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt with COPD and frequent admissions for
   respiratory failure.  Likely ARDS given sudden onset, P/F ratio<200,
   pulmonary edema which is unlikely cardiogenic. Also has underlying
   pseudomonas pneumonia. She was initially admitted to and placed on
   BiPAP, but required intubtion after desat. ABG with worsening
   hypercarbia and hypoxia. Possible PNA given pseudomonas in sputum. CXR
   showed b/l diffuse infiltrates/effusions R>L.
   - Consider placement of an esophageal balloon to clarify PEEP therapy.
   - If the patient is dialyzed, her respiratory status might improve.
   - CXR in AM
   - cont methylpred
   - albuterol/ ipratropium nebs
   #. Tachycardia: Pt with MAT/a-flutter Her rates on admission were as
   high as 150-180's.  She was started on amio (bolus 150mg, then 1mg/hr)
   due to hypotension nodal agents were deferred.  Her fast rate is likely
   contributing to her hypotension.  She was previously controlled on po
   lopressor, dilt and dig. Also on the differential is possible
   underlying PE driving her tachycardia, although given Hct drop would
   not start anti-coagulation.  Additionally, sepsis and pain also likely
   driving her tachycardia. The patient has troponin leaks, likely due to
   demand ischemia.
   - Received an amiodarone load on [**8-16**]. Decided to D/C because did not
   want to give oral med. Also, hypotensive and BP will not tolerate
   amiodarone.
   - Pending studies: echo, LENIs (to r/o DVTs and possible PE)
   - hold on anti-coagulation given bleeding and Hct drop
   ARF: Renal failure was initially likely pre-renal given sepsis. It has
   likely progressed to ischemic ATN. Has poor UOP.
   - consulted renal to dialyze patient.
   - need to renally dose medications and avoid nephrotoxins.
   - f/u renal note.
   #. DIC:.Increased PT/PTT, LDH. Thrombocytopenia (HIT negative at OSH).
   Fibrinogen elevated
   --Stable, will cont to monitor and trend.
   --Will treat underlying sepsis and see if DIC improves.
   --spoke about starting activated protein C, but risks of bleeding
   outweigh benefits.
   .
   #. Anemia: Pt
s crit continues to fall. Unsure if dilution. Doubt
   active bleeding.
   - active T&C
   - transfuse 1 unit of blood
   - check Hct q 4 hr
   - Consider CT of torso if continues to bleed.
   .
   Abdominal striae with oozing fluid: KUB done last night and cannot see
   anything.
   - consider abdominal CT if status worsens.
   #. UTI: See above. Growing proteus in urine from OSH.
   - cont amikacin for now
   - f/u UCx
   - obtain OSH records from [**Hospital3 **]
   .
   #. Pseudomonas Sputum from OSH. GPC, GNR in sputum at [**Hospital1 54**]: growing

   CXR was reportly normal at OSH. Is being covered with amikacin.
   - CXR

   - OSH sensitivies need to be obtained
   - cont amikacin,  meropenem
   .

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

**Patient Demographics:**

* Age: 55 years old
* Gender: Female
* Admitted with a history of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), respiratory failure, and a-fib

**Current Condition:**

* Septic shock with MODS (Multi-Organ Dysfunction Syndrome)
* Respiratory failure with Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) and worsening pulmonary edema
* Acute Renal Failure (ARF) with anuria
* Lactic acidosis with elevated lactate levels
* Thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy
* Altered level of consciousness with dilated pupils and minimal responsiveness
* Hypotension requiring pressors
* Persistent tachycardia
* Anemia and bandemia

**Laboratory Results:**

* White Blood Cell Count (WBC): 2.6
* Hematocrit (Hct): 26%
* Platelet count: 22
* International Normalized Ratio (INR): 1.8
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.3
* Lactic Acid: 5.7 mmol/L
* Blood cultures: growing gram-positive cocci and gram-negative rods

**Imaging Studies:**

* Chest X-ray (CXR) showing worsening diffuse bilateral airspace disease and effusions

**Medications:**

* Broad-spectrum antibiotics: linezolid, amikacin, meropenem, and voriconazole
* Pressors: dopamine and levophed
* Vasopressin: 0.01 units/min
* Corticosteroids: hydrocortisone
* Anticoagulation: enoxaparin

**Plan:**

* Continue aggressive supportive care for septic shock, including pressors and vasopressin
* Monitor lactate levels and adjust therapy accordingly
* Consider continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) or intermittent hemodialysis (IHD)
* Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics and antifungal therapy
* Monitor for bleeding and adjust anticoagulation therapy as needed
* Continue stress hydrocortisone and consider activated protein C (APC) therapy
* Consider extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) or venovenous extracorporeal life support (VV-ECLS)

**Potential Complications:**

* Ischemic bowel due to persistent shock and pressors
* Cardiac arrest due to poor cardiac function and high risk of arrhythmias
* Bleeding due to coagulopathy and thrombocytopenia
* Infection due to prolonged hospitalization and immunosuppression

**Family and Goals of Care:**

* Family has been informed of the patient's condition and has chosen to continue full code status
* Goals of care are to provide aggressive supportive care and trial CVVH, with a focus on improving the patient's quality of life

**Next Steps:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's condition and adjust therapy as needed
* Repeat gas and labs as pending
* Consider updating the family on the patient's condition and discussing goals of care

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old female with a complex medical condition, including:

1. Septic shock: The patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever, and RR, and has a likely source of infection from respiratory, urinary, or line infections.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient has COPD and has been intubated due to respiratory distress. She has worsening hypercarbia and hypoxia, and may have ARDS or pulmonary edema.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient has anuria and is at risk for further kidney damage due to sepsis and hypotension.
4. Multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS): The patient has MODS with septic shock, ARF, ARDS, and worsening lactic acidosis.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a platelet count of 22, which is low.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient has an elevated PT and PTT, and a low fibrinogen level.
7. Anemia: The patient has a low hemoglobin level and is at risk for further bleeding.
8. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis with a high white blood cell count and a high lactate level.
9. Hypotension: The patient has hypotension despite being on two pressors.
10. Tachycardia: The patient has a tachycardia with a heart rate of 130 beats per minute.

The patient's condition is critical, and she is at high risk for further deterioration. The patient's family has been informed of her condition, and they understand that she is in MODS and is on full vent support. The family is not ready to make any changes to the patient's code status at this time.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Aggressive supportive care: The patient will continue to receive aggressive supportive care, including pressors, vasopressors, and ventilatory support.
2. Broad-spectrum antibiotics: The patient will continue to receive broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover potential infections.
3. Fungal coverage: The patient will continue to receive fungal coverage with voriconazole.
4. Renal replacement therapy: The patient may require renal replacement therapy, including CVVH, to manage her AKI.
5. Cardiac output monitoring: The patient will continue to receive cardiac output monitoring to optimize her hemodynamic status.
6. Stress hydrocortisone: The patient will continue to receive stress hydrocortisone to manage her adrenal insufficiency.
7. Continuous cardiac output monitoring: The patient will continue to receive continuous cardiac output monitoring with the Vigileo system.

The patient's prognosis is grim, and she is at high risk for further deterioration. The patient's family will continue to be updated on her condition, and a plan will be developed to manage her care and ensure her comfort.

   Assesment: This is a 55 year-old female with a history of COPD and
   respiratory failure, MAT/a-flutter, chronic steroid use, who was
   intially admitted to [**Hospital3 **] with MAT/a-fib, respiratory
   distress, intubated and treated for UTI and transferred per family
   request.
   .
   Plan:
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever,
   and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate elevated.  Likely source is
   respiratory, although urinary and line infection are possible. The
   patient has been at [**Hospital3 **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial
   infections are high on the differential. The patient's hypotension is
   likely multifactorial.  Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter
   with rapid rate, likely infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line
   infection.  She was placed on levophed gtt and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna
   vs effusion vs pulm edema vs ARDS.
   Hemodynamics
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12
   - IV fluid boluses and Levophed and Dopamine to maintain MAP > 65 and
   UOP > 30cc/hr. Avoid Neo due to vasoconstrictive effects on
   limbs/organs.
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30
   - consulted renal for possible CVVH to remove fluid. +~11 liters over
   24 hours
   Infection: broad coverage for C.diff, gram +/- including VRE. Bactrim
   because long term steroid use.
   - Sputum (4+ GNR, 4+GPC in [**Hospital1 54**] culture, OSH culture showing
   pseudomonas) and blood (GPC, GNR in [**Hospital1 54**] culture). Reported VRE
   surveillance positive in OSH culture.
   - Started linezolid ([**8-16**]), amikacin (started at OSH), flagyl.
   - cont treatment with Amikacin given Proteus in urine and pseudomonas
   in sputum, treat with linezolid for VRE coverage (positive screen at
   OSH), meropenem for pseudomonas double coverage, voriconazole (at risk
   of fungal infection given chronic steroid use)
   - Need to renally dose medications
   - f/u urine, sputum, blood cxs.
   - consider activated protein C in patient, however, bleeding risks
   outweigh benefit.
   - trend WBC, fever curve
   - ID approval of abx.
   Metabolic: Has AG metabolic acidosis, likely due to lactate. With low
   pH on ABG, worry about cardiac asystole.
   - Continue to trend lactate
   - dialysis will help with lactate clearance
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt with COPD and frequent admissions for
   respiratory failure.  Likely ARDS given sudden onset, P/F ratio<200,
   pulmonary edema which is unlikely cardiogenic. Also has underlying
   pseudomonas pneumonia. She was initially admitted to and placed on
   BiPAP, but required intubtion after desat. ABG with worsening
   hypercarbia and hypoxia. Possible PNA given pseudomonas in sputum. CXR
   showed b/l diffuse infiltrates/effusions R>L.
   - Consider placement of an esophageal balloon to clarify PEEP therapy.
   - If the patient is dialyzed, her respiratory status might improve.
   - CXR in AM
   - cont methylpred
   - albuterol/ ipratropium nebs
   #. Tachycardia: Pt with MAT/a-flutter Her rates on admission were as
   high as 150-180's.  She was started on amio (bolus 150mg, then 1mg/hr)
   due to hypotension nodal agents were deferred.  Her fast rate is likely
   contributing to her hypotension.  She was previously controlled on po
   lopressor, dilt and dig. Also on the differential is possible
   underlying PE driving her tachycardia, although given Hct drop would
   not start anti-coagulation.  Additionally, sepsis and pain also likely
   driving her tachycardia. The patient has troponin leaks, likely due to
   demand ischemia.
   - Received an amiodarone load on [**8-16**]. Decided to D/C because did not
   want to give oral med. Also, hypotensive and BP will not tolerate
   amiodarone.
   - Pending studies: echo, LENIs (to r/o DVTs and possible PE)
   - hold on anti-coagulation given bleeding and Hct drop
   ARF: Renal failure was initially likely pre-renal given sepsis. It has
   likely progressed to ischemic ATN. Has poor UOP.
   - consulted renal to dialyze patient.
   - need to renally dose medications and avoid nephrotoxins.
   - f/u renal note.
   #. DIC:.Increased PT/PTT, LDH. Thrombocytopenia (HIT negative at OSH).
   Fibrinogen elevated
   --Stable, will cont to monitor and trend.
   --Will treat underlying sepsis and see if DIC improves.
   --spoke about starting activated protein C, but risks of bleeding
   outweigh benefits.
   .
   #. Anemia: Pt
s crit continues to fall. Unsure if dilution. Doubt
   active bleeding.
   - active T&C
   - transfuse 1 unit of blood
   - check Hct q 4 hr
   - Consider CT of torso if continues to bleed.
   .
   Abdominal striae with oozing fluid: KUB done last night and cannot see
   anything.
   - consider abdominal CT if status worsens.
   #. UTI: See above. Growing proteus in urine from OSH.
   - cont amikacin for now
   - f/u UCx
   - obtain OSH records from [**Hospital3 **]
   .
   #. Pseudomonas Sputum from OSH. GPC, GNR in sputum at [**Hospital1 54**]: growing
   from sputum. Question as to whether colonization vs active infection.
   CXR was reportly normal at OSH. Is being covered with amikacin.
   - CXR
   - f/u sputum cx
   - OSH sensitivies need to be obtained
   - cont amikacin,  meropenem
   .
   #. IDDM: Pt on steriods. Will initiated ISS and lantus 24U q12.
   Monitor QACHS FS and cover with ISS.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now. D/C tubefeeds.
   Glycemic Control:  HISS.
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2165-8-16**] 10:30 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2165-8-17**] 03:27 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: boots
   Stress ulcer: pantoprazole
   VAP:  elevate HOB
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: Will speak to family today about pt
   condition
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU level of care

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), pulmonary hypertension, and chronic steroid use. She was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with acute respiratory failure, sepsis, and acute kidney injury (AKI).

The patient's condition is deteriorating, with worsening respiratory failure, sepsis, and AKI. She has a high risk of developing multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) and death.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated lactate levels (5.7 mmol/L)
* Elevated troponin levels (0.37 ng/mL)
* Elevated creatinine levels (1.3 mg/dL)
* Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels (22 mg/dL)
* Elevated white blood cell count (WBC) (3.3 x 10^9/L)
* Elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) levels (49 mg/L)
* Elevated D-dimer levels (172 ng/mL)

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray (CXR) showing bilateral diffuse infiltrates and effusions
* Computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest showing bilateral pulmonary edema

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Sepsis
* Acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
* Pulmonary hypertension
* Chronic steroid use

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* AKI
* MODS
* Cardiac arrest
* Bleeding
* Infection
* Organ dysfunction

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Mechanical ventilation
* Antibiotics (linezolid, amikacin, meropenem)
* Vasopressors (levophed, dopamine)
* Fluid resuscitation
* Renal replacement therapy (RRT)
* Activated protein C (APC) therapy
* Corticosteroids
* Anticoagulation therapy

 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
 SEPSIS, SEVERE (WITH ORGAN DYSFUNCTION)

   Assesment: This is a 55 year-old female with a history of COPD and
   respiratory failure, MAT/a-flutter, chronic steroid use, who was
   intially admitted to [**Hospital3 **] with MAT/a-fib, respiratory
   distress, intubated and treated for UTI and transferred per family
   request.
   .
   Plan:
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever,
   and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate elevated.  Likely source is
   respiratory, although urinary and line infection are possible. The
   patient has been at [**Hospital3 **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial
   infections are high on the differential. The patient's hypotension is
   likely multifactorial.  Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter
   with rapid rate, likely infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line
   infection.  She was placed on levophed gtt and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna
   vs effusion vs pulm edema vs ARDS.
   Hemodynamics
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12
   - IV fluid boluses and Levophed and Dopamine to maintain MAP > 65 and
   UOP > 30cc/hr. Avoid Neo due to vasoconstrictive effects on
   limbs/organs.
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30
   - consulted renal for possible CVVH to remove fluid. +~11 liters over
   24 hours
   Infection: broad coverage for C.diff, gram +/- including VRE. Bactrim
   because long term steroid use.
   - Sputum (4+ GNR, 4+GPC in [**Hospital1 54**] culture, OSH culture showing
   pseudomonas) and blood (GPC, GNR in [**Hospital1 54**] culture). Reported VRE
   surveillance positive in OSH culture.
   - Started linezolid ([**8-16**]), amikacin (started at OSH), flagyl.
   - cont treatment with Amikacin given Proteus in urine and pseudomonas
   in sputum, treat with linezolid for VRE coverage (positive screen at
   OSH), meropenem for pseudomonas double coverage, voriconazole (at risk
   of fungal infection given chronic steroid use)
   - Need to renally dose medications
   - f/u urine, sputum, blood cxs.
   - consider activated protein C in patient, however, bleeding risks
   outweigh benefit.
   - trend WBC, fever curve
   - ID approval of abx.
   Metabolic: Has AG metabolic acidosis, likely due to lactate. With low
   pH on ABG, worry about cardiac asystole.
   - Continue to trend lactate
   - dialysis will help with lactate clearance
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt with COPD and frequent admissions for
   respiratory failure.  Likely ARDS given sudden onset, P/F ratio<200,
   pulmonary edema which is unlikely cardiogenic. Also has underlying
   pseudomonas pneumonia. She was initially admitted to and placed on
   BiPAP, but required intubtion after desat. ABG with worsening
   hypercarbia and hypoxia. Possible PNA given pseudomonas in sputum. CXR
   showed b/l diffuse infiltrates/effusions R>L.
   - Consider placement of an esophageal balloon to clarify PEEP therapy.
   - If the patient is dialyzed, her respiratory status might improve.
   - CXR in AM
   - cont methylpred
   - albuterol/ ipratropium nebs
   #. Tachycardia: Pt with MAT/a-flutter Her rates on admission were as
   high as 150-180's.  She was started on amio (bolus 150mg, then 1mg/hr)
   due to hypotension nodal agents were deferred.  Her fast rate is likely
   contributing to her hypotension.  She was previously controlled on po
   lopressor, dilt and dig. Also on the differential is possible
   underlying PE driving her tachycardia, although given Hct drop would
   not start anti-coagulation.  Additionally, sepsis and pain also likely
   driving her tachycardia. The patient has troponin leaks, likely due to
   demand ischemia.
   - Received an amiodarone load on [**8-16**]. Decided to D/C because did not
   want to give oral med. Also, hypotensive and BP will not tolerate
   amiodarone.
   - Pending studies: echo, LENIs (to r/o DVTs and possible PE)
   - hold on anti-coagulation given bleeding and Hct drop
   ARF: Renal failure was initially likely pre-renal given sepsis. It has
   likely progressed to ischemic ATN. Has poor UOP.
   - consulted renal to dialyze patient.
   - need to renally dose medications and avoid nephrotoxins.
   - f/u renal note.
   #. DIC:.Increased PT/PTT, LDH. Thrombocytopenia (HIT negative at OSH).
   Fibrinogen elevated
   --Stable, will cont to monitor and trend.
   --Will treat underlying sepsis and see if DIC improves.
   --spoke about starting activated protein C, but risks of bleeding
   outweigh benefits.
   .
   #. Anemia: Pt
s crit continues to fall. Unsure if dilution. Doubt
   active bleeding.
   - active T&C
   - transfuse 1 unit of blood
   - check Hct q 4 hr
   - Consider CT of torso if continues to bleed.
   .
   Abdominal striae with oozing fluid: KUB done last night and cannot see
   anything.
   - consider abdominal CT if status worsens.
   #. UTI: See above. Growing proteus in urine from OSH.
   - cont amikacin for now
   - f/u UCx
   - obtain OSH records from [**Hospital3 **]
   .
   #. Pseudomonas Sputum from OSH. GPC, GNR in sputum at [**Hospital1 54**]: growing
   from sputum. Question as to whether colonization vs active infection.
   CXR was reportly normal at OSH. Is being covered with amikacin.
   - CXR
   - f/u sputum cx
   - OSH sensitivies need to be obtained
   - cont amikacin,  meropenem
   .
   #. IDDM: Pt on steriods. Will initiated ISS and lantus 24U q12.
   Monitor QACHS FS and cover with ISS.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now. D/C tubefeeds.
   Glycemic Control:  HISS.
   Lines:

   Multi Lumen - [**2165-8-17**] 03:27 PM

   DVT: boots
   Stress ulcer: pantoprazole
   VAP:  elevate HOB

   Disposition: ICU level of care<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), pulmonary hypertension, and chronic steroid use, who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with respiratory distress, intubated, and treated for urinary tract infection (UTI). She has developed acute renal failure, acute respiratory failure, septic shock, and tachycardia. The patient's condition is critical, and she requires close monitoring and aggressive management to address her multiple organ dysfunction.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock is likely due to respiratory, urinary, or line infection, and may progress to multi-organ dysfunction.
2. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's worsening pulmonary congestion and bilateral pleural effusions suggest a high risk of developing ARDS.
3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's acute renal failure may progress to AKI, requiring dialysis and close monitoring of fluid and electrolyte balance.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's tachycardia may be due to underlying cardiac conditions, such as pulmonary hypertension or ischemic heart disease, which may require further evaluation and management.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient's increased PT/PTT, LDH, and thrombocytopenia suggest a high risk of developing disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), which may require anticoagulation therapy.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be due to dilution, bleeding, or other underlying causes, which requires close monitoring and transfusion support.
7. Infection: The patient's UTI, pseudomonas pneumonia, and possible line infection require ongoing antimicrobial therapy and close monitoring of culture results.
8. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may require correction with bicarbonate therapy and close monitoring of electrolyte balance.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, including temperature, heart rate, and blood pressure.
2. Maintain a high level of suspicion for sepsis and acute respiratory distress syndrome.
3. Continue antimicrobial therapy for UTI, pseudomonas pneumonia, and possible line infection.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and consider dialysis if AKI progresses.
5. Consider placement of an esophageal balloon to clarify PEEP therapy.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and consider further evaluation and management for cardiac complications.
7. Monitor the patient's coagulation status and consider anticoagulation therapy for DIC.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusion support if necessary.
9. Monitor the patient's metabolic acidosis and consider correction with bicarbonate therapy.
10. Consider placement of an arterial line to monitor the patient's blood pressure and cardiac status.

 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])

   Assesment: This is a 55 year-old female with a history of COPD and
   respiratory failure, MAT/a-flutter, chronic steroid use, who was
   intially admitted to [**Hospital3 **] with MAT/a-fib, respiratory
   distress, intubated and treated for UTI and transferred per family
   request.
   .
   Plan:
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever,
   and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate elevated.  Likely source is
   respiratory, although urinary and line infection are possible. The
   patient has been at [**Hospital3 **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial
   infections are high on the differential. The patient's hypotension is
   likely multifactorial.  Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter
   with rapid rate, likely infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line
   infection.  She was placed on levophed gtt and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna
   vs effusion vs pulm edema vs ARDS.
   Hemodynamics
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12
   - IV fluid boluses and Levophed and Dopamine to maintain MAP > 65 and
   UOP > 30cc/hr. Avoid Neo due to vasoconstrictive effects on
   limbs/organs.
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30
   - consulted renal for possible CVVH to remove fluid. +~11 liters over
   24 hours
   Infection: broad coverage for C.diff, gram +/- including VRE. Bactrim
   because long term steroid use.
   - Sputum (4+ GNR, 4+GPC in [**Hospital1 54**] culture, OSH culture showing
   pseudomonas) and blood (GPC, GNR in [**Hospital1 54**] culture). Reported VRE
   surveillance positive in OSH culture.
   - Started linezolid ([**8-16**]), amikacin (started at OSH), flagyl.
   - cont treatment with Amikacin given Proteus in urine and pseudomonas
   in sputum, treat with linezolid for VRE coverage (positive screen at
   OSH), meropenem for pseudomonas double coverage, voriconazole (at risk
   of fungal infection given chronic steroid use)
   - Need to renally dose medications
   - f/u urine, sputum, blood cxs.
   - consider activated protein C in patient, however, bleeding risks
   outweigh benefit.
   - trend WBC, fever curve
   - ID approval of abx.
   Metabolic: Has AG metabolic acidosis, likely due to lactate. With low
   pH on ABG, worry about cardiac asystole.
   - Continue to trend lactate
   - dialysis will help with lactate clearance
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt with COPD and frequent admissions for
   respiratory failure.  Likely ARDS given sudden onset, P/F ratio<200,
   pulmonary edema which is unlikely cardiogenic. Also has underlying
   pseudomonas pneumonia. She was initially admitted to and placed on
   BiPAP, but required intubtion after desat. ABG with worsening
   hypercarbia and hypoxia. Possible PNA given pseudomonas in sputum. CXR
   showed b/l diffuse infiltrates/effusions R>L.
   - Consider placement of an esophageal balloon to clarify PEEP therapy.
   - If the patient is dialyzed, her respiratory status might improve.
   - CXR in AM
   - cont methylpred
   - albuterol/ ipratropium nebs
   #. Tachycardia: Pt with MAT/a-flutter Her rates on admission were as
   high as 150-180's.  She was started on amio (bolus 150mg, then 1mg/hr)
   due to hypotension nodal agents were deferred.  Her fast rate is likely
   contributing to her hypotension.  She was previously controlled on po
   lopressor, dilt and dig. Also on the differential is possible
   underlying PE driving her tachycardia, although given Hct drop would
   not start anti-coagulation.  Additionally, sepsis and pain also likely
   driving her tachycardia. The patient has troponin leaks, likely due to
   demand ischemia.
   - Received an amiodarone load on [**8-16**]. Decided to D/C because did not
   want to give oral med. Also, hypotensive and BP will not tolerate
   amiodarone.
   - Pending studies: echo, LENIs (to r/o DVTs and possible PE)
   - hold on anti-coagulation given bleeding and Hct drop
   ARF: Renal failure was initially likely pre-renal given sepsis. It has
   likely progressed to ischemic ATN. Has poor UOP.
   - consulted renal to dialyze patient.
   - need to renally dose medications and avoid nephrotoxins.
   - f/u renal note.
   #. DIC:.Increased PT/PTT, LDH. Thrombocytopenia (HIT negative at OSH).
   Fibrinogen elevated
   --Stable, will cont to monitor and trend.
   --Will treat underlying sepsis and see if DIC improves.
   --spoke about starting activated protein C, but risks of bleeding
   outweigh benefits.
   .
   #. Anemia: Pt
s crit continues to fall. Unsure if dilution. Doubt
   active bleeding.
   - active T&C
   - transfuse 1 unit of blood
   - check Hct q 4 hr
   - Consider CT of torso if continues to bleed.
   .
   Abdominal striae with oozing fluid: KUB done last night and cannot see
   anything.
   - consider abdominal CT if status worsens.
   #. UTI: See above. Growing proteus in urine from OSH.
   - cont amikacin for now
   - f/u UCx
   - obtain OSH records from [**Hospital3 **]
   .
   #. Pseudomonas Sputum from OSH. GPC, GNR in sputum at [**Hospital1 54**]: growing
   from sputum. Question as to whether colonization vs active infection.
   CXR was reportly normal at OSH. Is being covered with amikacin.
   - CXR
   - f/u sputum cx
   - OSH sensitivies need to be obtained
   - cont amikacin,  meropenem
   .
   #. IDDM: Pt on steriods. Will initiated ISS and lantus 24U q12.
   Monitor QACHS FS and cover with ISS.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now. D/C tubefeeds.
   Glycemic Control:  HISS.
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2165-8-16**] 10:30 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2165-8-17**] 03:27 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: boots
   Stress ulcer: pantoprazole
   VAP:  elevate HOB
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: Will speak to family today about pt
   condition

   MICU ATTENDING PROGRESS NOTE
   I saw and examined the patient and was physically present with the ICU
   team for the key portions of the services provided. I agree with the
   resident note, including the assessment and plan. I would emphasize and
   add the following points:
   55 yo F with septic shock and MODS (ARF, ARDS, worsening lactic
   acidosis).  She remains on 100% fio2 via vent.  She remains on 2
   pressors with progressive acidosis and rising lactate despite
   aggressive resuscitation.  She is anuric and in ARF.  Her antibx were
   broadened and vori added.  She is growing gpc pairs/clusters and gnr
   from blood and sputum.
   Tm 104   MAP 65   HR 130
s   RR 26   96%  cvp 11    11L +
   AC 400/26/18/100%  -->  7.16/69/60    plt 33
   intubated, unresponsive, pupils are dilated but rx,  coarse BS,
   tachy/[**Last Name (un) **], BS decreased, soft, diffuse echymosis/wheeping, cool
   /mottled ext
   Labs reviewed--persistent bandemia, leukopenic WBC 2.6,  hct 26,  plt
   22,  INR 1.8, cr 1.3, lactate 5.7
   CXR with worsening diffuse b/l ASD/edema R > L and effusions
   Micro reviewed
   Primary issues include:
     * Septic shock
     * Hypotension
     * Progressive lactic acidosis,
     * MOSD
     * resp failure/ards/pulm edema,
     * persistent tachycardia
     * arf,
     * persistent bandemia,
     * anemia
     * thrombocytopenia/coagulopathy
     * altered level of consciousness
   MODS in setting of progressive septic shock.  Continues to decline
   despite aggressive management. Her prognosis for recovery is grim.  We
   continue to  update family and address goals of care.  Will continue
   aggressive supportive care for septic shock, maintaining maps > 60 with
   pressors. Is now 11L pos.  Her oxygenation remains poor on 100%
   fio2/peep 18.  Rising lactate raises concern for ischemic bowel in
   setting of persistent shock and pressors. Continue broad empiric
   antibacterial and fungal coverage-linezolid, amikacin (follow levels),
   [**Last Name (un) 430**], flagyl, and vori. D/c bactrim as low suspicion for PCP. [**Name10 (NameIs) **] data.
   Continue stress hydrocort.  Continuous cardiac output monitoring w/
   vigileo. Trend lactate, lytes, SVO2.  Continue vent support, ards net
   TVs.  We are unable to wean O2.  She is maxed on what we can do from
   vent standpoint in term of her acid base status.  Renal is following,
   but given grim prognosis, CVVH would only be temporizing. We again
   discussed xigris, but her progressive coagulopathy and thrombocytopenia
   (and ? bleeding at admit) make her a poor candidate. ICU:  SSI, NPO, L
   fem, r IJ, radial a line, boots, PPI, sq hep, full code
   Remainder of plan as outlined in resident note
   Patient is critically ill

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old female admitted to the ICU with a complex medical condition. She has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and has been intubated due to respiratory failure. The patient has developed septic shock, acute kidney injury (ARF), and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 104°F (40°C)
* Heart rate: 133 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 100/52 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 26 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP): 11 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results are:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 2.6 K/μL
* Hematocrit (Hct): 26%
* Platelet count (PLT): 22 K/μL
* International normalized ratio (INR): 1.8
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.3 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 5.7 mmol/L

The patient's imaging studies are:

* Chest X-ray (CXR): Worsening bilateral diffuse infiltrates and effusions, with a possible diagnosis of ARDS.

The patient's medications are:

* Dopamine: 8 mcg/kg/min
* Heparin sodium: 10,000 units/day
* Pantoprazole: 40 mg/day
* Linezolid: 600 mg/day
* Amikacin: 15 mg/kg/day
* Meropenem: 1 g/day
* Voriconazole: 200 mg/day
* Bactrim: 160 mg/day

The patient's plan of care is as follows:

* Septic shock management: Maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) > 60 mmHg with pressors, and consider activated protein C therapy.
* ARF management: Continue to monitor and trend creatinine levels, and consider dialysis if the patient's condition worsens.
* ARDS management: Continue to provide mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 18 cmH2O, and consider placement of an esophageal balloon to clarify PEEP therapy.
* Tachycardia management: Continue to monitor and trend heart rate, and consider treatment with beta blockers or calcium channel blockers.
* Anemia management: Continue to monitor and trend hemoglobin levels, and consider transfusion of packed red blood cells if the patient's anemia worsens.
* Thrombocytopenia management: Continue to monitor and trend platelet count, and consider treatment with platelet transfusions if the patient's thrombocytopenia worsens.

The patient's potential medical complications are:

* Septic shock
* ARF
* ARDS
* Tachycardia
* Anemia
* Thrombocytopenia
* Coagulopathy
* Altered level of consciousness

The patient's prognosis is grim, and the ICU team is discussing goals of care with the family. The patient's condition is critical, and the ICU team is providing aggressive supportive care, including mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and broad empiric antibiotic coverage.

   Assesment: This is a 55 year-old female with a history of COPD and
   respiratory failure, MAT/a-flutter, chronic steroid use, who was
   intially admitted to [**Hospital3 **] with MAT/a-fib, respiratory
   distress, intubated and treated for UTI and transferred per family
   request.
   .
   Plan:
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever,
   and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate elevated.  Likely source is
   respiratory, although urinary and line infection are possible. The
   patient has been at [**Hospital3 **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial
   infections are high on the differential. The patient's hypotension is
   likely multifactorial.  Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter
   with rapid rate, likely infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line
   infection.  She was placed on levophed gtt and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna
   vs effusion vs pulm edema vs ARDS.
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12
   - IV fluid boluses and Levophed and Dopamine to maintain MAP > 65 and
   UOP > 30cc/hr. Avoid Neo due to vasoconstrictive effects on
   limbs/organs.
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30 if remains in septic shock
   - cont treatment with Amikacin given Proteus in urine and pseudomonas
   in sputum, treat with linezolid for VRE coverage (positive screen at
   OSH), meropenem for pseudomonas double coverage, bactrim for PCP (use
   of chronic steroids)
   - check amikacin peak and trough
   - empiric coverage with meropenem
   - CXR in AM
   - f/u blood, urine and sputum cultures
   - Trend WBC count fever curve.
   - call OSH for sensi
   - stress dose steriods
   - cooling blankets prn
   - ID consult in AM regarding abx regimen
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt with COPD and frequent admissions for
   respiratory failure.  Likely ARDS given sudden onset, P/F ratio<200,
   pulmonary edema, unlikely cardiogenic. Also has underlying pseudomonas
   pneumonia. She was initially admitted to and placed on BiPAP, but
   required intubtion after desat. ABG with worsening hypercarbia and
   hypoxia. Possible PNA given pseudomonas in sputum and as well as

   due to hypotension nodal agents were deferred.  Her fast rate is likely
   contributing to her hypotension.  She was previously controlled on po
   lopressor, dilt and dig. Also on the differential is possible
   underlying PE driving her tachycardia, although given Hct drop would
   not start anti-coagulation.  Additionally, sepsis and pain also likely
   driving her tachycardia.

   - LENI to r/o DVT

   OSH. Pt with multiple ecchymosis on exam.  No evidence of active
   bleeding. Other possiblities could be RP or intraperitonea bleed.
   - active T&C 4U
   - Transfuse 2U pRBC and repeat Hct
   - hemolysis labs

   - if continues to drop Hct plan for CT-torso

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of COPD, pulmonary hypertension, and chronic steroid use. She was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory failure, septic shock, and acute kidney injury. She has a temperature spike, worsening gases, and poor urine output. The patient has multiple infections, including UTI, pseudomonas pneumonia, and VRE. She is being treated with antibiotics, vasopressors, and diuretics.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing further organ dysfunction due to her septic shock and multiple infections.
2. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's respiratory failure and worsening hypercarbia and hypoxia may progress to ARDS.
3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's renal failure and oliguria may worsen, leading to further complications.
4. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): The patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation may lead to VAP.
5. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient's immobility and risk factors may increase her risk of developing DVT.
6. Pulmonary Embolism (PE): The patient's tachycardia and hypoxia may be due to PE, which could worsen her respiratory failure.
7. Anemia: The patient's Hct drop and ecchymosis may indicate bleeding or hemolysis, which could worsen her anemia.
8. Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC): The patient's thrombocytopenia and bleeding may indicate DIC.
9. Infection Control: The patient's multiple infections and risk factors may increase her risk of developing further infections.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient is at high risk of developing further complications due to her septic shock, respiratory failure, and multiple infections. The plan includes:

* IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12
* IV fluid boluses and vasopressors to maintain MAP > 65 and UOP > 30cc/hr
* Treatment with antibiotics, including amikacin, meropenem, and linezolid
* CXR and blood cultures to monitor for further infections
* Trend WBC count and fever curve
* ID consult in AM regarding antibiotic regimen
* Stress dose steroids
* Cooling blankets prn
* ECHO ordered to monitor for cardiac dysfunction
* LENI to r/o DVT
* Active T&C 4U and transfusion of pRBCs as needed
* Hemolysis labs and guaiac stools to monitor for bleeding
* CT-torso if Hct continues to drop
* ICU care, including nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

   Assesment: This is a 55 year-old female with a history of COPD and
   respiratory failure, MAT/a-flutter, chronic steroid use, who was
   intially admitted to [**Hospital3 **] with MAT/a-fib, respiratory
   distress, intubated and treated for UTI and transferred per family
   request.
   .
   Plan:
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever,
   and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate elevated.  Likely source is
   respiratory, although urinary and line infection are possible. The
   patient has been at [**Hospital3 **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial
   infections are high on the differential. The patient's hypotension is
   likely multifactorial.  Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter
   with rapid rate, likely infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line
   infection.  She was placed on levophed gtt and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna
   vs effusion vs pulm edema vs ARDS.
   Hemodynamics
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12
   - IV fluid boluses and Levophed and Dopamine to maintain MAP > 65 and
   UOP > 30cc/hr. Avoid Neo due to vasoconstrictive effects on
   limbs/organs.
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30
   - consulted renal for possible CVVH to remove fluid. +~11 liters over
   24 hours
   Infection: broad coverage for C.diff, gram +/- including VRE. Bactrim
   because long term steroid use.
   - Sputum (4+ GNR, 4+GPC in [**Hospital1 54**] culture, OSH culture showing
   pseudomonas) and blood (GPC, GNR in [**Hospital1 54**] culture). Reported VRE
   surveillance positive in OSH culture.
   - Started linezolid ([**8-16**]), amikacin (started at OSH), flagyl.
   - cont treatment with Amikacin given Proteus in urine and pseudomonas
   in sputum, treat with linezolid for VRE coverage (positive screen at
   OSH), meropenem for pseudomonas double coverage, voriconazole (at risk
   of fungal infection given chronic steroid use)
   - Need to renally dose medications
   - f/u urine, sputum, blood cxs.
   - consider activated protein C in patient, however, bleeding risks
   outweigh benefit.
   - trend WBC, fever curve
   - ID approval of abx.
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt with COPD and frequent admissions for
   respiratory failure.  Likely ARDS given sudden onset, P/F ratio<200,
   pulmonary edema, unlikely cardiogenic. Also has underlying pseudomonas
   pneumonia. She was initially admitted to and placed on BiPAP, but
   required intubtion after desat. ABG with worsening hypercarbia and
   hypoxia. Possible PNA given pseudomonas in sputum and as well as
   chronic aspirations. CXR showed b/l diffuse infiltrates/effusions R>L.
   - CXR in AM
   - cont methylpred
   - albuterol/ ipratropium nebs
   #. Tachycardia: Pt with MAT/a-flutter Her rates on admission were as
   high as 150-180's.  She was started on amio (bolus 150mg, then 1mg/hr)
   due to hypotension nodal agents were deferred.  Her fast rate is likely
   contributing to her hypotension.  She was previously controlled on po
   lopressor, dilt and dig. Also on the differential is possible
   underlying PE driving her tachycardia, although given Hct drop would
   not start anti-coagulation.  Additionally, sepsis and pain also likely
   driving her tachycardia.
   - If continue Amio, need to switch to PO.
   - ECHO ordered
   - hold on anti-coagulation given bleeding and Hct drop
   - LENI to r/o DVT
   #. DIC:. HIT negative at OSH. Stable, will cont to monitor and trend.
   .
   #. Anemia: Pt Hct on admission was 21.9. This is down from 25 at the
   OSH. Pt with multiple ecchymosis on exam.  No evidence of active
   bleeding. Other possiblities could be RP or intraperitonea bleed.
   - active T&C 4U
   - Transfuse 2U pRBC and repeat Hct
   - hemolysis labs
   - guaiac stools
   - if continues to drop Hct plan for CT-torso
   .
   Abdominal striae with oozing fluid: KUB done last night and cannot see
   anything.
   #. UTI: See above. Growing proteus in urine.
   - cont amikacin for now
   - repeat UA/UCx
   .
   #. Pseudomonas Sputum: growing from sputum. Question as to whether
   colonization vs active infection. CXR was reportly normal at OSH. Is
   being covered with amikacin.
   - CXR
   - f/u sputum cx
   - cont amikacin,  meropenem

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), respiratory failure, and chronic steroid use. She was initially admitted with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), intubated, and treated for urinary tract infection (UTI). She has been at risk for nosocomial infections due to her prolonged hospital stay. The patient's condition has deteriorated, with worsening pulmonary congestion, bilateral pleural effusions, and acute kidney injury (AKI).

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and lactate levels
* Decreased hemoglobin (Hb) and hematocrit (Hct)
* Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels
* Positive cultures for gram-positive cocci (GPC) and gram-negative rods (GNR) in blood and sputum
* Positive VRE surveillance in OSH culture

The patient's clinical condition is complicated by:

* Septic shock with multi-organ dysfunction
* Respiratory failure with ARDS and pseudomonas pneumonia
* Tachycardia with MAT/a-flutter
* Anemia with possible bleeding or intraperitoneal bleed
* DIC with stable platelet count
* UTI with growing proteus in urine
* Pseudomonas sputum colonization or infection
* IDDM with steroid use

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis with multi-organ dysfunction
2. Respiratory failure with ARDS and pseudomonas pneumonia
3. Tachycardia with MAT/a-flutter
4. Anemia with possible bleeding or intraperitoneal bleed
5. DIC with potential bleeding complications
6. UTI with possible kidney damage
7. Pseudomonas sputum colonization or infection with potential respiratory complications
8. IDDM with potential hyperglycemia and ketoacidosis

Recommendations:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics for sepsis and UTI
2. Initiate renal replacement therapy (RRT) for AKI
3. Monitor and manage respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy
4. Continue anticoagulation therapy to prevent DVT and PE
5. Monitor and manage tachycardia with beta-blockers and anti-arrhythmic agents
6. Monitor and manage anemia with blood transfusions and iron supplements
7. Monitor and manage DIC with platelet transfusions and anticoagulation therapy
8. Monitor and manage IDDM with insulin therapy and glucose monitoring

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), respiratory failure, and chronic steroid use. She was initially admitted to the hospital with myocardial infarction (MAT) and respiratory distress, intubated, and treated for urinary tract infection (UTI). She was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to septic shock and multi-organ failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: She has acute respiratory failure, with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 68, and is on mechanical ventilation. She has a history of COPD and frequent admissions for respiratory failure.
* Cardiovascular: She has tachycardia, likely due to sepsis and persistent fevers, and has a history of MAT/a-flutter. She was started on amiodarone, but it was discontinued due to hypotension.
* Renal: She has acute renal failure, likely due to pre-renal azotemia, which has progressed to ischemic acute tubular necrosis (ATN). She is anuric and is being dialyzed.
* Hematological: She has thrombocytopenia, likely due to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and has received one unit of platelets. Her platelet count is currently 20.
* Metabolic: She has metabolic acidosis, with a low pH on arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis, and is being treated with bicarbonate to try to ameliorate the acidosis.
* Infection: She has sepsis, likely due to pseudomonas pneumonia, and has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including linezolid, amikacin, and meropenem.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's PaO2/FiO2 ratio is 68, indicating a high risk of respiratory failure. She has a history of COPD and frequent admissions for respiratory failure.
* Cardiovascular instability: The patient's tachycardia and hypotension are likely due to sepsis and persistent fevers. She has a history of MAT/a-flutter and was started on amiodarone, but it was discontinued due to hypotension.
* Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely due to pre-renal azotemia, which has progressed to ischemic ATN. She is anuric and is being dialyzed.
* DIC: The patient's thrombocytopenia and elevated PT/PTT are consistent with DIC. She has received one unit of platelets and is being treated with anticoagulants.
* Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis is likely due to sepsis and is being treated with bicarbonate.
* Infection: The patient's sepsis is likely due to pseudomonas pneumonia, and she has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) for renal failure
* Mechanical ventilation for respiratory failure
* Broad-spectrum antibiotics for sepsis
* Anticoagulation for DIC
* Bicarbonate therapy for metabolic acidosis
* Sedation and analgesia for comfort
* Close monitoring of vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies.

   Assesment: This is a 55 year-old female with a history of COPD and
   respiratory failure, MAT/a-flutter, chronic steroid use, who was
   intially admitted to [**Hospital3 **] with MAT/a-fib, respiratory
   distress, intubated and treated for UTI and transferred per family
   request.
   .
   Plan:
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever,
   and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate elevated.  Likely source is
   respiratory, although urinary and line infection are possible. The
   patient has been at [**Hospital3 **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial
   infections are high on the differential. The patient's hypotension is
   likely multifactorial.  Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter
   with rapid rate, likely infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line
   infection.  She was placed on levophed gtt and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna
   vs effusion vs pulm edema vs ARDS.
   Hemodynamics
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12
   - IV fluid boluses and Levophed and Dopamine to maintain MAP > 65.
   Avoid Neo due to vasoconstrictive effects on limbs/organs.
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30
   - discussed w/ family pt started on CVVH
   Infection: broad coverage for C.diff, gram +/- including VRE. Bactrim
   because long term steroid use.
   - Sputum (4+ GNR, 4+GPC in [**Hospital1 54**] culture, OSH culture showing
   pseudomonas) and blood (GPC, GNR in [**Hospital1 54**] culture). Reported VRE
   surveillance positive in OSH culture.
   - Started linezolid ([**8-16**]), amikacin (started at OSH), flagyl.
   - cont treatment with Amikacin given Proteus in urine and pseudomonas
   in sputum, treat with linezolid for VRE coverage (positive screen at
   OSH), meropenem for pseudomonas double coverage, voriconazole (at risk
   of fungal infection given chronic steroid use)
   - Need to renally dose medications
   - f/u urine, sputum, blood cxs.
   - consider activated protein C in patient, however, bleeding risks
   outweigh benefit.
   - trend WBC, fever curve
   Metabolic: Has AG metabolic acidosis, likely due to lactate. With low
   pH on ABG, worry about cardiac asystole.
   - Continue to trend lactate
   - dialysis will help with lactate clearance
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt with COPD and frequent admissions for
   respiratory failure.  Likely ARDS given sudden onset, P/F ratio<200,
   pulmonary edema which is unlikely cardiogenic. Also has underlying
   pseudomonas pneumonia. She was initially admitted to and placed on
   BiPAP, but required intubtion after desat. ABG with worsening
   hypercarbia and hypoxia. Possible PNA given pseudomonas in sputum. CXR
   showed b/l diffuse infiltrates/effusions R>L.
   - patient is being dialyzed
   - repeat CXR in AM
   - cont methylpred
   - albuterol/ ipratropium nebs
   #. Tachycardia: Pt with MAT/a-flutter. Her rates on admission were as
   high as 150-180's.  She was started on amio (bolus 150mg, then 1mg/hr)
   due to hypotension nodal agents were deferred.  Her fast rate is likely
   contributing to her hypotension.  She was previously controlled on po
   lopressor, dilt and dig. Sepsis and persistent fevers are likely the
   cause of her tachycardia. The patient has troponin leaks, likely due to
   demand ischemia.
   - Received an amiodarone load on [**8-16**]. Decided to D/C because did not
   want to give oral med. Also, hypotensive and BP will not tolerate
   amiodarone.
   - Pending studies: echo, LENIs (to r/o DVTs and possible PE)
   - hold on anti-coagulation given bleeding and Hct drop
   ARF: Renal failure was initially likely pre-renal given sepsis. It has
   likely progressed to ischemic ATN. Currently aniuric.
   - being dialyzed.
   - need to renally dose medications and avoid nephrotoxins.
   - f/u renal note.
   #. DIC:.Increased PT/PTT, LDH. Thrombocytopenia (HIT negative at OSH).
   Fibrinogen elevated
   --Stable, will cont to monitor and trend.
   --Will treat underlying sepsis and see if DIC improves.
   --spoke about starting activated protein C, but risks of bleeding
   outweigh benefits.
   .
   #. Anemia: Pt
s Hct currently stable at 26.1.
   - active T&C
   - check Hct q 4 hr
   - Consider CT of torso if continues to bleed.
   .
   Abdominal striae with oozing fluid, total output ~3L. KUB done on [**8-17**]
   did not show anything.
   - consider abdominal CT if status worsens.
   #. UTI: See above. Growing proteus in urine from OSH.
   - cont amikacin for now
   - f/u UCx
   - obtain OSH records from [**Hospital3 **]
   .
   #. Pseudomonas Sputum from OSH. GPC, GNR in sputum at [**Hospital1 54**]: growing
   from sputum. Question as to whether colonization vs active infection.
   CXR was reportly normal at OSH. Is being covered with amikacin.
   - CXR

   - cont amikacin,  meropenem

   #. IDDM: Pt on steriods. Will initiated ISS and lantus 24U q12.

Summary:

The patient is a 55-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), pulmonary hypertension, and chronic steroid use. She was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with acute respiratory failure, septic shock, and acute kidney injury. The patient has been diagnosed with severe sepsis, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and acute kidney injury. She is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, vasopressors, and dialysis.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing further complications due to sepsis, including organ dysfunction, septic shock, and death.
2. ARDS: The patient's ARDS may progress to respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation and potentially leading to respiratory arrest.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may progress to chronic kidney disease, requiring long-term dialysis or kidney transplantation.
4. Pulmonary hypertension: The patient's pulmonary hypertension may worsen, leading to right ventricular failure and death.
5. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD): The patient's COPD may worsen, leading to respiratory failure and death.
6. Pseudomonas pneumonia: The patient's pseudomonas pneumonia may progress to respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation and potentially leading to respiratory arrest.
7. Line infection: The patient's line infection may lead to sepsis, septic shock, and death.
8. Urinary tract infection (UTI): The patient's UTI may lead to sepsis, septic shock, and death.
9. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient is at risk of developing DVT, which may lead to pulmonary embolism and death.
10. Abdominal complications: The patient's abdominal striae with oozing fluid may lead to abdominal compartment syndrome, requiring emergency surgery.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's condition is critical, and she requires close monitoring and treatment. The plan includes:

1. Sepsis treatment: Broad-spectrum antibiotics, vasopressors, and dialysis.
2. ARDS treatment: Mechanical ventilation, oxygen therapy, and corticosteroids.
3. Acute kidney injury treatment: Dialysis and renally dosed medications.
4. Pulmonary hypertension treatment: Oxygen therapy and vasodilators.
5. COPD treatment: Bronchodilators, corticosteroids, and oxygen therapy.
6. Pseudomonas pneumonia treatment: Antibiotics and oxygen therapy.
7. Line infection treatment: Antibiotics and removal of the line.
8. UTI treatment: Antibiotics and close monitoring.
9. DVT prophylaxis: Boots and anticoagulation therapy.
10. Abdominal complications treatment: Close monitoring and potential surgical intervention.

The patient's family has been informed of her condition, and the patient has a full code status. The patient will require ongoing close monitoring and treatment in the ICU.

   Assesment: This is a 55 year-old female with a history of COPD and
   respiratory failure, MAT/a-flutter, chronic steroid use, who was
   intially admitted to [**Hospital3 **] with MAT/a-fib, respiratory
   distress, intubated and treated for UTI and transferred per family
   request.
   .
   Plan:
   .
   #. Septic Shock - Patient meets SIRS criteria with tachycardia, fever,
   and RR and 45%bands. Pt lactate elevated.  Likely source is
   respiratory, although urinary and line infection are possible. The
   patient has been at [**Hospital3 **] and resident of [**Hospital1 630**] so nosocomial
   infections are high on the differential. The patient's hypotension is
   likely multifactorial.  Contributing factors include her MAT/a-flutter
   with rapid rate, likely infection from UTI, pseudomonas pna or line
   infection.  She was placed on levophed gtt and neo gtt.  CXR showed pna
   vs effusion vs pulm edema vs ARDS.
   Hemodynamics
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12
   - IV fluid boluses and Levophed and Dopamine to maintain MAP > 65 and
   UOP > 30cc/hr. Avoid Neo due to vasoconstrictive effects on
   limbs/organs.
   - Transfuse for Hct > 30
   - consulted renal for possible CVVH to remove fluid. +~11 liters over
   24 hours
   Infection: broad coverage for C.diff, gram +/- including VRE. Bactrim
   because long term steroid use.
   - Sputum (4+ GNR, 4+GPC in [**Hospital1 54**] culture, OSH culture showing
   pseudomonas) and blood (GPC, GNR in [**Hospital1 54**] culture). Reported VRE
   surveillance positive in OSH culture.
   - Started linezolid ([**8-16**]), amikacin (started at OSH), flagyl.
   - cont treatment with Amikacin given Proteus in urine and pseudomonas
   in sputum, treat with linezolid for VRE coverage (positive screen at
   OSH), meropenem for pseudomonas double coverage, voriconazole (at risk
   of fungal infection given chronic steroid use)
   - Need to renally dose medications
   - f/u urine, sputum, blood cxs.
   - consider activated protein C in patient, however, bleeding risks
   outweigh benefit.
   - trend WBC, fever curve
   - ID approval of abx.
   Metabolic: Has AG metabolic acidosis, likely due to lactate. With low
   pH on ABG, worry about cardiac asystole.
   - Continue to trend lactate
   - dialysis will help with lactate clearance
   #. Respiratory Failure: Pt with COPD and frequent admissions for
   respiratory failure.  Likely ARDS given sudden onset, P/F ratio<200,
   pulmonary edema which is unlikely cardiogenic. Also has underlying
   pseudomonas pneumonia. She was initially admitted to and placed on
   BiPAP, but required intubtion after desat. ABG with worsening
   hypercarbia and hypoxia. Possible PNA given pseudomonas in sputum. CXR
   showed b/l diffuse infiltrates/effusions R>L.
   - Consider placement of an esophageal balloon to clarify PEEP therapy.
   - If the patient is dialyzed, her respiratory status might improve.
   - CXR in AM
   - cont methylpred

   #. Tachycardia: Pt with MAT/a-flutter Her rates on admission were as
   high as 150-180's.  She was started on amio (bolus 150mg, then 1mg/hr)
   due to hypotension nodal agents were deferred.  Her fast rate is likely
   contributing to her hypotension.  She was previously controlled on po
   lopressor, dilt and dig. Also on the differential is possible
   underlying PE driving her tachycardia, although given Hct drop would
   not start anti-coagulation.  Additionally, sepsis and pain also likely
   driving her tachycardia. The patient has troponin leaks, likely due to
   demand ischemia.
   - Received an amiodarone load on [**8-16**]. Decided to D/C because did not

   amiodarone.
   - Pending studies: echo, LENIs (to r/o DVTs and possible PE)
   - hold on anti-coagulation given bleeding and Hct drop
   ARF: Renal failure was initially likely pre-renal given sepsis. It has
   likely progressed to ischemic ATN. Has poor UOP.
   - consulted renal to dialyze patient.
